Multiple meanings.text: The ongoing tense is similar to "ing" verbs in English, but not exactly. Whereas in English you can choose whether to say "he is running" or "he runs," in Hebrew and Aramaic, both of these meanings would be expressed with the ongoing form ie הוא רץ, and so it often isn't clear in Hebrew and Aramaic whether we are speaking about someone who is doing something
(ie, "he is running") or about someone who does something

Past.text: The ongoing tense can be used in the past tense, for example הוא היה רץ, meaning "he used to run" or "he used to be running." If you wanted to say "he ran," you would just use the regular past tense and not the past version of the ongoing tense.

Present.text: The ongoing tense can be used in the present tense, for example, הוא רץ, meaning "he is running" or "he runs."

Future.text: The ongoing tense can be used in the future tense, for example, הוא יהיה רץ, meaning "he will be running." If you wanted to say "he will run," you would just use the regular future tense and not the past version of the ongoing tense.

Technical name.text: The ongoing tense has a technical name in grammar, the "participle."
